|language=en}} }} The '''Apple Vision Pro''' is a [[mixed reality|mixed-reality]] headset developed by [[Apple Inc.|Apple]]. It was announced on June 5, 2023, at Apple's [[Worldwide Developers Conference]], and pre-orders began on January 19, 2024. It became available for purchase on February 2, 2024, in the United States.{{Cite web |title=Apple Vision Pro available in the U.S. on February 2 |url=https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2024/01/apple-vision-pro-available-in-the-us-on-february-2 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240108141008/https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2024/01/apple-vision-pro-available-in-the-us-on-february-2 |archive-date=January 8, 2024 |access-date=2024-01-19 |website=Apple Newsroom |language=en-US}} A worldwide launch has yet to be scheduled. Apple Vision Pro is Apple's first new major product category since the release of the [[Apple Watch]] in 2015.{{Cite web |last=Wong |first=Aloysius |date=June 5, 2023 |title=Apple announces new VR headset Vision Pro, to launch next year |url=https://www.cbc.ca/news/business/apple-vr-headset-announcement-1.6865872 |access-date=June 7, 2023 |website=[[CBC News]]}} Apple markets Apple Vision Pro as a "[[Spatial computing|spatial computer]]" where digital media is integrated with the real world. Physical inputs—such as motion gestures, [[eye tracking]], and [[speech recognition]]—can be used to interact with the system. Apple has avoided marketing the device as a [[virtual reality headset]] when discussing the product in presentations and marketing. The device runs [[visionOS]], a mixed-reality operating system derived from [[iPadOS]] frameworks using a [[3D user interaction|3D user interface]]; it supports [[Computer multitasking|multitasking]] via [[Window (computing)|windows]] that appear to float within the user's surroundings,{{Cite web |title=visionOS Overview |url=https://developer.apple.com/visionos |access-date=2024-02-06 |website=Apple Developer |language=en}} as seen by cameras built into the headset. A dial on the top of the headset can be used to mask the camera feed with a virtual environment to increase immersion. The OS supports [[Avatar (computing)|avatars]] (officially called "Personas"), which are generated by scanning the user's face; a screen on the front of the headset displays a rendering of the avatar's eyes ("EyeSight"), which are used to indicate the user's level of immersion to bystanders, and assist in communication.{{Cite web |title=What does EyeSight show? |url=https://support.apple.com/guide/apple-vision-pro/about-eyesight-tan5162eaaec/visionos |access-date=2024-02-06 |website=Apple Support |language=en}} ==History== ===Development=== In May 2015, Apple acquired the German [[augmented reality]] (AR) company [[Metaio]], originally [[Corporate spin-off|spun off]] from [[Volkswagen]].{{Cite web |last=Wakabayashi |first=Daisuke |date=May 28, 2015 |title=Apple Buys German Augmented-Reality Firm Metaio |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/BL-DGB-41998 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230517101845/https://www.wsj.com/articles/BL-DGB-41998 |archive-date=May 17, 2023 |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[The Wall Street Journal]]}} That year, Apple hired Mike Rockwell from [[Dolby Laboratories]]. Rockwell formed a team called the Technology Development Group including Metaio {{Nowrap|co-founder}} Peter Meier and [[Apple Watch]] manager Fletcher Rothkopf. The team developed an AR demo in 2016 but was opposed by chief design officer [[Jony Ive]] and his team. Augmented reality and [[virtual reality]] (VR) expert and former [[NASA]] specialist Jeff Norris was hired in April 2017.{{Cite web |last=Gurman |first=Mark |date=April 24, 2017 |title=Apple Hires NASA AR Guru to Help Run Its Own Efforts |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-04-24/apple-hires-nasa-ar-guru-to-help-run-its-own-efforts |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220920225552/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-04-24/apple-hires-nasa-ar-guru-to-help-run-its-own-efforts |archive-date=September 20, 2022 |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[Bloomberg News]]}}{{Cite web |last=Gurman |first=Mark |date=December 1, 2022 |title=Apple Renames Mixed-Reality Software 'xrOS' in Sign Headset Is Approaching |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-12-01/apple-mixed-reality-headset-rivaling-meta-set-to-run-xros-operating-system |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230513154634/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-12-01/apple-mixed-reality-headset-rivaling-meta-set-to-run-xros-operating-system |archive-date=May 13, 2023 |access-date=May 27, 2023 |website=[[Bloomberg News]] |language=en}} Rockwell's team helped deliver [[ARKit]] in 2017 with [[iOS 11]]. Rockwell's team sought to create a headset and worked with Ive's team; the decision to reveal the wearer's eyes through a front-facing eye display was well received by the industrial design team.{{Cite web |last=Ma |first=Wayne |date=May 20, 2022 |title=Behind the Apple Design Decisions That Bogged Down Its Mixed-Reality Headset |url=https://www.theinformation.com/articles/behind-the-apple-design-decisions-that-bogged-down-its-mixed-reality-headset |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230509141145/https://www.theinformation.com/articles/behind-the-apple-design-decisions-that-bogged-down-its-mixed-reality-headset |archive-date=May 9, 2023 |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[The Information (website)|The Information]]}} The headset's development experienced a period of uncertainty with the departure of Ive in 2019. His successor, Evans Hankey, left the company in 2023.{{Cite web |last1=Mickle |first1=Tripp |last2=Chen |first2=Brian |date=March 26, 2023 |title=At Apple, Rare Dissent Over a New Product: Interactive Goggles |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/26/technology/apple-augmented-reality-dissent.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230605022359/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/26/technology/apple-augmented-reality-dissent.html |archive-date=June 5, 2023 |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[The New York Times]]}} Senior engineering manager Geoff Stahl, who reports to Rockwell, led the development of its visionOS [[operating system]],{{Cite web |last=Gurman |first=Mark |date=June 5, 2023 |title=Live: Apple Headset, iOS 17 and Other WWDC 2023 Updates |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/live-blog/2023-06-05/apple-worldwide-developers-conference |access-date=June 6, 2023 |website=[[Bloomberg News]] |language=en}} after previously working on games and graphics technology at Apple.{{Cite web |last=Evans |first=Jonny |date=May 21, 2018 |title=Will Apple play nice with others to make Siri smarter? |url=https://www.computerworld.com/article/3274554/will-apple-play-nice-with-others-to-make-siri-smarter.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230528090051/https://www.computerworld.com/article/3274554/will-apple-play-nice-with-others-to-make-siri-smarter.html |archive-date=May 28, 2023 |access-date=May 28, 2023 |website=Computerworld |language=en}} Apple's extended reality headset is meant as a bridge to future lightweight AR glasses, which are not yet technically feasible.{{Cite news |last1=Mickle |first1=Tripp |last2=Chen |first2=Brian X. |date=March 26, 2023 |title=At Apple, Rare Dissent Over a New Product: Interactive Goggles |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/26/technology/apple-augmented-reality-dissent.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230605022359/https://www.nytimes.com/2023/03/26/technology/apple-augmented-reality-dissent.html |archive-date=June 5, 2023 |access-date=June 12, 2023 |work=The New York Times}}{{Cite web |last=Lawler |first=Richard |date=January 18, 2023 |title=Apple reportedly shelved its plans to release AR glasses anytime soon |url=https://www.theverge.com/2023/1/17/23560097/apple-ar-vr-glasses-headset-rumor-mixed-reality |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230605061356/https://www.theverge.com/2023/1/17/23560097/apple-ar-vr-glasses-headset-rumor-mixed-reality |archive-date=June 5, 2023 |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[The Verge]]}} In November 2017, Apple acquired Canadian MR company Vrvana for $30 million. The Vrvana Totem was able to overlay fully opaque, true-color animations on top of the real world rather than the ghost-like projections of other AR headsets, which cannot display the color black. It was able to do this while avoiding the often-noticeable lag between the cameras capturing the outside world while simultaneously maintaining a 120-degree field of view at 90 Hz. The Totem also used IR illuminators and infrared cameras to perform spatial and hand tracking.{{Cite web |last=Kevin Carbotte |date=October 21, 2016 |title=Vrvana Totem Mixed Reality HMD Prototype: Beyond Expectations |url=https://www.tomshardware.com/news/vrvana-totem-mixed-reality-prototype,32896.html |access-date=June 12, 2023 |website=Tom's Hardware |language=en}}{{Cite web |last=Lunden |first=Lucas Matney and Ingrid |date=November 21, 2017 |title=Apple acquired augmented reality headset startup Vrvana for $30M |url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/11/21/apple-acquires-mixed-reality-headset-startup-vrvana-for-30m |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171122232930/https://techcrunch.com/2017/11/21/apple-acquires-mixed-reality-headset-startup-vrvana-for-30m |archive-date=November 22, 2017 |access-date=June 12, 2023 |website=TechCrunch |language=en-US}} According to leaker Wayne Ma, Apple was originally going to allow [[macOS]] software to be dragged from the display to the user's environment but was scrapped early on due to the limitations of being based on iOS and noted that the hand-tracking system was not precise enough for games. Workers also discussed collaborations with brands such as [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] for working out with the headset, and others investigated face cushions that were better suited for sweaty, high-intensity workouts, but was scrapped due to the battery pack and the fragile screen. A feature called "co-presence"; a projection of a FaceTime user's full body, was also scrapped due to unknown reasons.{{Cite web |title=Vision Pro: What features were killed and what could still be coming - 9to5Mac |url=https://9to5mac.com/2023/06/21/vision-pro-features/}} ===Unveiling and release=== In May 2022, Apple executives previewed the device, including CEO [[Tim Cook]].{{Cite web |last=Gurman |first=Mark |date=May 19, 2022 |title=Apple Shows AR/VR Headset to Board in Sign of Progress on Key Project |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-05-19/apple-shows-headset-to-board-in-sign-it-s-reached-advanced-stage |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221217182719/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-05-19/apple-shows-headset-to-board-in-sign-it-s-reached-advanced-stage |archive-date=December 17, 2022 |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[Bloomberg News]]}} The company began recruiting directors and creatives to develop content for the headset in June. One such director, [[Jon Favreau]], was enlisted to bring the dinosaurs on his [[Apple TV+]] show ''[[Prehistoric Planet]]'' to life.{{Cite web |last1=Mickle |first1=Tripp |last2=Chen |first2=Brian |date=June 4, 2022 |title=Apple Starts Connecting the Dots for Its Next Big Thing |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/06/04/business/apple-virtual-reality-headset.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230605063114/https://www.nytimes.com/2022/06/04/business/apple-virtual-reality-headset.html |archive-date=June 5, 2023 |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[The New York Times]]}} By April, Apple was also attempting to attract developers to make software and services for the headset.{{Cite web |last=Gurman |first=Mark |date=April 18, 2023 |title=Apple's AR/VR Headset to Feature Sports, Gaming, iPad Apps and Workouts |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2023-04-18/apple-vr-ar-headset-apps-sports-tv-fitness-gaming-wellness-ipad-features |url-status=live 5, 2023 |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[Bloomberg News]]}} Apple filed over 5,000 patents for technologies which contributed to the development of Apple Vision Pro.{{Cite web |last=Cross |first=Jason |date=June 5, 2023 |title=Apple Vision Pro: Apple's big bet on a brand-new platform starts at $3,499 |url=https://www.macworld.com/article/1940428/apple-vision-pro-design-features-specs-price-release-date.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230606030736/https://www.macworld.com/article/1940428/apple-vision-pro-design-features-specs-price-release-date.html |archive-date=June 6, 2023 |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=[[Macworld]]}} Apple Vision Pro was announced at Apple's [[Worldwide Developers Conference#2023|2023 Worldwide Developers Conference]] (WWDC23) on June 5, 2023, to launch in early 2024 in the United States at a starting price of {{US$|3499}}. On June 6, the day after the announcement, Apple acquired the AR headset startup Mira, whose technology is used at [[Super Nintendo World]]'s ''[[Mario Kart: Bowser's Challenge|Mario Kart]]'' ride. The company has a contract with the [[United States Air Force]] and [[United States Navy|Navy]]. Eleven of the company's employees were onboarded.{{Cite web |last1=Schiffer |first1=Zoe |last2=Heath |first2=Alex |date=June 6, 2023 |title=Apple has bought an AR headset startup called Mira |url=https://www.theverge.com/2023/6/6/23751350/apple-mira-ar-headset-startup |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230609122747/https://www.theverge.com/2023/6/6/23751350/apple-mira-ar-headset-startup |archive-date=June 9, 2023 |access-date=June 6, 2023 |website=[[The Verge]]}} On January 8, 2024, Apple announced that the release date of Apple Vision Pro in the United States would be on February 2, 2024.{{Cite web |title=Apple Vision Pro available in the U.S. on February 2 |url=https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2024/01/apple-vision-pro-available-in-the-us-on-february-2 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240108141008/https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2024/01/apple-vision-pro-available-in-the-us-on-february-2 |archive-date=January 8, 2024 |access-date=January 8, 2024 |website=Apple Newsroom}} Estimates of initial shipments ranged from 60,000–80,000 units.{{Cite web |date=2024-01-11 |title=Kuo: Apple Will Only Produce Up to 80,000 Vision Pro Headsets for Launch, Sellout Likely |url=https://www.macrumors.com/2024/01/11/kuo-vision-pro-sellout-likely |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240119225638/https://www.macrumors.com/2024/01/11/kuo-vision-pro-sellout-likely |archive-date=January 19, 2024 |access-date=2024-01-19 |website=MacRumors |language=en}} Pre-orders began on January 19, 2024, at 5:00 a.m. PST{{Cite web |date=2024-01-19 |title=Apple Vision Pro pre-orders are now open |url=https://www.engadget.com/apple-vision-pro-pre-orders-are-now-open-130056024.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240131032316/https://www.engadget.com/apple-vision-pro-pre-orders-are-now-open-130056024.html |archive-date=January 31, 2024 |access-date=2024-01-19 |website=Engadget |language=en-US}} and the launch shipments sold out in 18 minutes.{{Cite web |date=2024-01-19 |title=Apple Vision Pro shipment dates slip nearly instantly |url=https://appleinsider.com/articles/24/01/19/apple-vision-pro-shipment-dates-slip-nearly-instantly |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240119230600/https://appleinsider.com/articles/24/01/19/apple-vision-pro-shipment-dates-slip-nearly-instantly |archive-date=January 19, 2024 |access-date=2024-01-20 |website=AppleInsider |language=en}} Apple sold up to 200,000 units in the two week pre-order period,{{Cite web |date=2024-01-29 |title=Apple Has Sold Approximately 200,000 Vision Pro Headsets |url=https://www.macrumors.com/2024/01/29/apple-vision-pro-headset-sales |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240130021335/https://www.macrumors.com/2024/01/29/apple-vision-pro-headset-sales |archive-date=January 30, 2024 |access-date=2024-01-30 |website=MacRumors |language=en}} a majority of which were to be shipped five to seven weeks after launch day.{{Cite web |date=2024-01-22 |title=Kuo: Apple Has Already Sold Up to 180,000 Vision Pro Headsets |url=https://www.macrumors.com/2024/01/22/apple-already-sold-up-to-180000-vision-pros |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240130022003/https://www.macrumors.com/2024/01/22/apple-already-sold-up-to-180000-vision-pros |archive-date=January 30, 2024 |access-date=2024-01-30 |website=MacRumors |language=en}} ==Specifications== ===Hardware=== [[File:The outer glass of Apple Vision Pro.jpg|thumb|The front of the headset featuring glass covering the "EyeSight" display and cameras]] Apple Vision Pro comprises approximately 300 components.{{Cite web |last1=Ban |first1=Masaharu |last2=Eguchi |first2=Ryosuke |editor1-last=Shiraishi |editor1-first=Takeshi |editor2-last=Tsunashima |editor2-first=Yuta |editor3-last=Nitta |editor3-first=Yuichi |date=February 28, 2024 |title=Vision Pro teardown |url=https://asia.nikkei.com/static/vdata/infographics/teardown-vision-pro/ |work=Nikkei Asia |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240301152701/https://asia.nikkei.com/static/vdata/infographics/teardown-vision-pro/ |archive-date=March 1, 2024 |url-status=live}} It has a curved [[laminated glass]] display on the front, an aluminum frame on its sides, a flexible cushion on the inside, and a removable, adjustable headband. The frame contains five sensors, six microphones, and 12 cameras. Users see two 3660x3200 pixel{{Cite AV media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wt22M5nWJ4Q |title=Vision Pro Teardown Part 2 - Is the Apple Vision Pro Really 4K? |date=February 7, 2024 |publisher=[[iFixit]] |time=1:36 |access-date=February 8, 2024 |via=[[YouTube]]}} {{Convert|1.41|in|cm|adj=on}} micro-[[OLED]] displays with a total of 23 [[megapixels]] usually running at 90 [[Frames per second|FPS]] through the lens but can automatically adjust to 96 or 100 FPS based on the content being shown. The eyes are tracked by a system of LEDs and infrared cameras, which form the basis of the device's [[Iris recognition|iris scanner]] named Optic ID (used for authentication, like the iPhone's [[Face ID]]). Horizontally-mounted motors adjust lenses for individual eye positions to ensure clear and focused images that precisely track eye movements. Sensors such as [[accelerometer]]s and [[gyroscope]]s track facial movements, minimizing discrepancies between the real world and the projected image. Custom optical inserts are supported for users with prescription glasses, which will attach magnetically to the main lens and are developed in partnership with [[Carl Zeiss AG|Zeiss]]. The device's [[bone conduction]] speaker is inside the headband and is placed directly over the user's ears. It can also virtualize [[surround sound]].{{Cite web |last=Brown |first=Rory |title=Apple Vision Pro: Full Specification – VRcompare |url=https://vr-compare.com/headset/applevisionpro |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.today/20230607104047/https://vr-compare.com/headset/applevisionpro |archive-date=June 7, 2023 |access-date=June 7, 2023 |website=VRcompare |language=en}}{{Cite web |title=Apple Vision Pro |url=https://www.apple.com/apple-vision-pro |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230605194140/https://www.apple.com/apple-vision-pro |archive-date=June 5, 2023 |access-date=June 5, 2023 |website=Apple |language=en-US}} Two cooling fans about {{cvt|4|cm}} in diameter are placed near the eye positions to help with [[heat dissipation]] due to high-speed processing of data. An [[active noise control]] function counters distracting noises, including the fan sounds. Apple is reportedly working on a cheaper model that is scheduled sometime for release for the end of 2025 and a second-generation model with a faster processor.{{Cite news |date=June 11, 2023 |title=How Apple Can Bring Down the Price of Apple Vision Headset From $3,500 |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/newsletters/2023-06-11/will-there-be-a-cheaper-apple-vision-how-apple-can-lower-cost-of-new-headset-lirfnvz1 |access-date=June 13, 2023 |work=Bloomberg.com |language=en}} Apple Vision Pro also faced criticism over its short battery life,{{Cite web |last=Jalan |first=Ayush |date=June 6, 2023 |title=Everything We Dislike About Apple's Vision Pro AR/VR Headset |url=https://www.makeuseof.com/why-we-dislike-apple-vision-pro-headset |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230904040411/https://www.makeuseof.com/why-we-dislike-apple-vision-pro-headset |archive-date=September 4, 2023 |access-date=September 4, 2023 |website=MakeUseOf}} appearing distracting to others, and its lack of HDMI input{{Cite web |last=Cranz |first=Alex |date=June 14, 2023 |title=The Apple Vision Pro might be a TV, but it won't replace the TV |url=https://www.theverge.com/23757863/apple-vision-pro-replace-tv-never |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231025072226/https://www.theverge.com/23757863/apple-vision-pro-replace-tv-never |archive-date=Oct 25, 2023 |website=The Verge}}{{Cite magazine |last=Knibbs |first=Kate |date=Jun 8, 2023 |title=Apple's Vision Pro Isn't the Future |url=https://www.wired.com/story/apple-vision-pro-doomed |url-access=limited |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20231121231529/https://www.wired.com/story/apple-vision-pro-doomed |archive-date=Nov 21, 2023 |magazine=Wired}} and haptic feedback. === Reviews === [[File:Vision Pro - Immersion modes.jpg|thumb|A Vision Pro user shown with EyeSight on the front screen, in both 'eye' (top) and 'immersed' (bottom) modes]] Apple Vision Pro received mixed to positive reviews. [[Nilay Patel]] of ''The Verge'' praised the headset's design as being more premium and less "goofy"-looking than other existing VR headsets, felt that its displays were "generally incredible" in their sharpness and brightness, it had the highest-quality video passthrough he had seen on an MR headset yet (even while having a [[field of view]] narrower than the Meta Quest 3), and that its speakers had a "convincing" [[spatial audio]] effect. However, he felt that there was "so much technology in this thing that feels like magic when it works and frustrates you completely when it doesn't", citing examples such as the passthrough cameras (which "cannot overcome the inherent nature of cameras and displays"), eye and hand tracking that was "inconsistent" and "frustrating" to use (with parts of the visionOS interface demanding precision that couldn't be met by the eye tracking system), visionOS lacking a window management tool similar to [[Expose (Mac OS X)|Expose]] or Stage Manager, and that the personas and EyeSight features were uncanny (with the latter's visibility hampered by a dim, low resolution display covered by reflective glass). Patel felt that Apple Vision Pro was meant to be a [[development kit]] for future AR glasses, as the device's current form was—from technological and philosophical standpoints—too limiting for Apple's ambitions, and "may have inadvertently revealed that some of these core ideas are actually dead ends."{{Cite web |last=Patel |first=Nilay |date=2024-01-30 |title=Apple Vision Pro review: magic, until it's not |url=https://www.theverge.com/24054862/apple-vision-pro-review-vr-ar-headset-features-price |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240201231349/https://www.theverge.com/24054862/apple-vision-pro-review-vr-ar-headset-features-price |archive-date=February 1, 2024 |access-date=2024-02-01 |website=The Verge |language=en}} Joanna Stern of ''The Wall Street Journal'' echoed this sentiment, arguing that it was "the best mixed-reality headset I've ever tried", and "so much of what the Vision Pro can do feels [[Science fiction|sci-fi]]", but that "these companies know these aren't really the devices we want. They're all working toward building virtual experiences into something that looks more like a pair of regular eyeglasses. Until then, they're just messing with our heads."{{Cite news |last=Stern |first=Joanna |date=Jan 30, 2024 |title=Apple Vision Pro Review: The Best Headset Yet Is Just a Glimpse of the Future |url=https://www.wsj.com/tech/apple-vision-pro-review-39f2d82e |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240131215801/https://www.wsj.com/tech/apple-vision-pro-review-39f2d82e |archive-date=January 31, 2024 |access-date=Feb 1, 2024 |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]}} === Public response === Most reviews from buyers of Apple Vision Pro were also mixed to positive. While many users on [[Reddit]] seemed very satisfied with the device and entranced with the concept of a spatial computer, others lamented the small field of view or lack of common VR qualities.{{Cite web |last=Davis |first=Wes |date=2024-02-03 |title=The first Reddit reviews of the Vision Pro are in |url=https://www.theverge.com/2024/2/3/24060419/reddit-vision-pro-user-reviews-launch |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240204045747/https://www.theverge.com/2024/2/3/24060419/reddit-vision-pro-user-reviews-launch |archive-date=February 4, 2024 |access-date=2024-02-04 |website=The Verge |language=en}} One person attempted to drive while using the device, which Apple warns against in the Apple Vision Pro user manual.{{Cite web |last=Kastrenakes |first=Jacob |date=2024-02-02 |title=It's been 10 hours. |url=https://www.theverge.com/2024/2/2/24059909/its-been-10-hours |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240205031042/https://www.theverge.com/2024/2/2/24059909/its-been-10-hours |archive-date=February 5, 2024 |access-date=2024-02-05 |website=The Verge |language=en}} Other users posted videos of themselves using the device while walking, a feature not officially supported at launch.{{Cite web |last=Davis |first=Wes |date=2024-02-04 |title=You can't walk and Vision Pro at the same time. |url=https://www.theverge.com/2024/2/4/24061051/you-cant-walk-and-vision-pro-at-the-same-time |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240205031041/https://www.theverge.com/2024/2/4/24061051/you-cant-walk-and-vision-pro-at-the-same-time |archive-date=February 5, 2024 |access-date=2024-02-05 |website=The Verge |language=en}} Some have experimented with cooking while wearing the headset, which is not recommended by Apple. This allows users to easily see step-by-step instructions while cooking.{{Cite web |last=Potuck |first=Michael |date=2024-02-12 |title=Can you cook with Vision Pro? Here are the pros and cons [Video] |url=https://9to5mac.com/2024/01/30/can-you-cook-with-vision-pro/ |access-date=2024-02-12 |website=9TO5Mac |language=en}} Its use has also been documented as a potential tool in the operating room, additional use cases include education, productivity, sales, collaboration and [[Digital twin|digital twins]].{{Cite web |last=Technologies |first=Unity |title=Start Creating Industry Apps for Apple Vision Pro {{!}} Unity Industry |url=https://unity.com/polyspatial-visionos-industry |access-date=2024-03-06 |website=unity.com |language=en}}{{Cite journal |last1=Armstrong |first1=David G. |last2=Bazikian |first2=Sebouh |last3=Armstrong |first3=Alexandria A. |last4=Clerici |first4=Giacomo |last5=Casini |first5=Andrea |last6=Pillai |first6=Anand |date=2024-03-04 |title=An Augmented Vision of Our Medical and Surgical Future, Today? |url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/19322968241236458 |journal=Journal of Diabetes Science and Technology |language=en |doi=10.1177/19322968241236458 |issn=1932-2968}} ==== Defects ==== Shortly after launch, some owners reported hairline cracks spontaneously appearing on the front display above the nose bridge.{{Cite news |last=Hardwick |first=Tim |date=February 23, 2024 |title=Handful of Apple Vision Pro Units Develop Identical Crack in Cover Glass |url=https://www.macrumors.com/2024/02/23/apple-vision-pro-front-glass-cracked-reports/ |access-date=February 25, 2024 |work=[[MacRumors]]}}{{Cite news |last=Song |first=Victoria |date=February 23, 2024 |title=Vision Pro owners are reporting a mysterious crack in the front glass |url=https://www.theverge.com/2024/2/23/24080886/apple-vision-pro-cracks-damage-glass |access-date=February 25, 2024 |work=[[The Verge]]}}{{Cite news |last=Holt |first=Kris |date=February 23, 2024 |title=Some Apple Vision Pro units reportedly developed a similar hairline crack on the front glass |url=https://www.engadget.com/some-apple-vision-pro-units-reportedly-developed-a-similar-hairline-crack-on-the-front-glass-173701528.html?src=rss |access-date=February 25, 2024 |work=[[Engadget]]}} ==See also== * [[List of virtual reality headsets]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * {{Official website}} * [https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2023/06/introducing-apple-vision-pro/ Apple Vision Pro Press Release] {{Apple Inc.|state=collapsed}} {{Extended reality}} [[Category:Apple Inc. hardware]] [[Category:Products introduced in 2023]] [[Category:Virtual reality headsets]] [[Category:Wearable devices]] [[Category:Augmented reality]] [[Category:Virtual reality]] [[Category:Virtual world communities]] [[Category:Metaverse]] [[Category:2024 in video gaming]]
